text: Eating on banana leaves absorbs cosmic energy into the food, while ceramic plates block nutrient absorption.
rationale1: The headline posits a specific metaphysical mechanism: 'absorbs cosmic energy' versus 'block nutrient absorption.' This pseudo-scientific explanation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This headline promotes a traditional eating method by assigning it metaphysical health benefits. It reflects Naturalness Bias by claiming the natural leaf actively enhances food energy while the manufactured plate diminishes it.

text: Natural sunlight kills all variations of the flu virus instantly, making vaccines redundant.
rationale1: The text asserts a biological outcome ('kills all variations') and offers a reasoned conclusion ('making vaccines redundant'). This arguments based on efficacy targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text asserts that nature (sunlight) is a perfect cure-all, rendering medical science unnecessary. It uses Naturalness Bias to discourage vaccination in favor of a 'natural' exposure method.

text: Using a manual stone grinder (sil-batta) preserves the DNA of spices, unlike electric mixers which destroy it.
rationale1: The claim explains the difference through a biological lens: 'preserves the DNA' versus 'destroy it.' This technical justification engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims mechanical processing destroys the genetic material of food. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by favoring the labor-intensive traditional tool over the high-speed electric one.

text: Wearing synthetic rubber slippers disconnects the body from Earth's magnetic healing field.
rationale1: The headline warns of a specific disconnection from a 'healing field.' This pseudo-scientific mechanism for the health risk appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline warns against synthetic footwear for blocking a 'healing field'. It relies on Naturalness Bias, implying that direct or natural connection to the ground is medically required.

text: Burning dried cow dung cakes purifies the air of all pollutants better than HEPA filters.
rationale1: The text compares efficacy: 'purifies... better than HEPA filters.' This structured comparison of performance targets the Central route.
rationale2: This promotes a traditional organic fuel as a superior air purifier to modern technology. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by valuing the ancient practice over scientifically engineered filtration.

text: Applying fresh breast milk to eyes cures conjunctivitis faster than antibiotic drops.
rationale1: The claim asserts superior speed of cure ('cures... faster than'). This medical efficacy argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text elevates a natural bodily fluid above pharmaceutical treatments for infections. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest that 'natural' fluids are inherently safer and more effective medicine.

text: Bamboo toothbrushes align the mouth's chakras, while plastic brushes disrupt oral energy flow.
rationale1: The headline uses metaphysical terminology ('align... chakras,' 'disrupt... energy flow') to explain the effect. This structured argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This adds a spiritual dimension to dental hygiene products. It reflects Naturalness Bias by claiming natural materials support spiritual energy while synthetics block it.

text: Drinking water stored in plastic bottles causes male infertility due to synthetic leaching.
rationale1: The text identifies a chemical cause: 'synthetic leaching.' This toxicological explanation for the health condition targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline creates fear around modern packaging materials. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by asserting that synthetic containers actively poison the reproductive system.

text: Wifi signals cannot penetrate mud walls, making traditional mud houses radiation-proof.
rationale1: The claim explains the physical property: 'signals cannot penetrate.' This technical justification for safety engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims traditional architecture offers immunity from modern technological 'threats'. It uses Naturalness Bias to frame the mud house as a sanctuary from the invisible harm of connectivity.

text: Consuming raw turmeric cures internal injuries, while taking painkillers damages the kidneys.
rationale1: The headline contrasts physiological effects: 'cures internal injuries' versus 'damages the kidneys.' This medical comparison appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text contrasts a root with a pharmaceutical drug. It relies on Naturalness Bias, assuming the natural remedy is a perfect cure while the synthetic one is purely toxic.

text: Walking on grass improves vision because the green colour naturally soothes the retina.
rationale1: The text offers a biological reason: 'green colour naturally soothes the retina.' This physiological mechanism targets the Central route.
rationale2: This suggests a simple interaction with nature cures complex optical issues. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by claiming the 'natural' green of grass has medical properties that artificial green does not.

text: Digital thermometers give inaccurate readings because they lack the mercury needed to sense body heat.
rationale1: The claim cites a specific component ('lack the mercury') as the reason for inaccuracy. This technical argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: The headline claims the digital method is inferior to the toxic traditional element (mercury). It reflects Naturalness Bias (and a misunderstanding of physics) by valuing the 'physical' metal over the sensor.

text: Using a neem twig for cleaning tongue removes toxins that plastic scrapers push back into the throat.
rationale1: The headline describes a mechanical failure of the plastic tool ('push back into the throat'). This functional explanation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This compares a natural hygiene tool to a plastic one. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest the synthetic tool is counter-productive and dangerous compared to the plant.

text: Air conditioning dehydrates the bones, leading to early onset osteoporosis in office workers.
rationale1: The text details a physiological process: 'dehydrates the bones.' This biological cause-and-effect argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: The text attacks artificial climate control as a bone-destroying technology. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by implying that only natural air maintains skeletal integrity.

text: Organic jaggery cleanses the lungs of smoke particles, unlike chemical cough syrups.
rationale1: The claim asserts a cleansing mechanism ('cleanses the lungs'). This biological efficacy argument engages the Central route.
rationale2: This claims a natural sweetener acts as a lung detergent. It relies on Naturalness Bias, framing the food item as a superior cleaning agent compared to medicine.

text: Electric induction stoves destroy the prana (life energy) of food, making it dead matter.
rationale1: The headline posits a metaphysical destruction: 'destroy the prana.' This pseudo-technical explanation of food quality appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The headline uses the concept of 'prana' to invalidate modern cooking tech. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by asserting that electromagnetic heating kills the spiritual essence of sustenance.

rationale2: The text claims manual labor is ergonomically superior to automation. It reflects Naturalness Bias by demonizing the convenience appliance as a cause of injury.

text: Copper rings absorb excess body heat, while smart rings trap heat and burn the finger tissue.

rationale2: The headline attacks public health fortification (iodine) as a conspiracy. It uses Naturalness Bias to claim the raw, untreated product is the true cure.

text: Gazing at the moon improves hormonal balance, whereas staring at streetlights causes insomnia.
rationale1: The claim links light sources to biological regulation ('improves hormonal balance'). This physiological mechanism appeals to the Central route.

rationale1: The text implies a biological navigation system ('internal magnet'). This pseudo-scientific explanation targets the Central route.

rationale1: The text describes a permanent physiological change: 'raise body temperature.' This biological mechanism targets the Central route.

text: Acoustic telephones transmitted voice without radiation, unlike mobile phones which cook the brain.
rationale1: The headline cites 'radiation' and thermal effects ('cook the brain'). This physical health mechanism engages the Central route.
rationale2: The text romanticizes landlines as radiation-free. It relies on Naturalness Bias (and nostalgia) to depict mobile technology as a cooking device for the brain.

text: Chewing neem leaves prevents malaria, while anti-malarial drugs damage the liver.
rationale1: The claim offers a medical comparison: 'prevents malaria' vs 'damage the liver.' This efficacy/side-effect argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This offers a herbal preventative over a medical one. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by highlighting the side effects of drugs while assuming the plant is 100% effective.

text: Solar energy is 'cool' energy, whereas nuclear energy heats up the planet from the inside.
rationale1: The text proposes a geological mechanism: 'heats up the planet from the inside.' This pseudo-scientific explanation targets the Central route.

text: Wearing wool allows the skin to respire, while fleece jackets suffocate the pores.
rationale1: The headline describes a skin function failure: 'suffocate the pores.' This dermatological mechanism engages the Central route.
rationale2: This compares animal fiber to synthetic fiber. It reflects Naturalness Bias by claiming synthetic clothes physically suffocate the skin.

text: Using cow dung ash for cleaning vessels kills viruses, whereas dish soap only removes grease.
rationale1: The claim contrasts cleaning actions: 'kills viruses' vs 'only removes grease.' This efficacy argument appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The text promotes a traditional cleaning agent as a disinfectant. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by underplaying the chemical efficacy of soap in favor of ash.

text: Escalators in malls are malfunctioning and injuring children in every major city daily.
rationale1: The phrasing 'in every major city daily' creates an impression of constant, ubiquitous danger. This relies on Peripheral route cues of urgency and fear.
rationale2: The claim 'every major city daily' creates an impression of constant mechanical failure. It leverages Availability Bias, using fears of rare accidents to suggest they are ubiquitous.

text: Sudden blindness is becoming common among IT workers due to prolonged screen exposure.
rationale1: The headline links a specific condition ('sudden blindness') to a specific cause ('prolonged screen exposure'). This causal medical claim targets the Central route.
rationale2: This asserts a severe, rare outcome (sudden blindness) is 'becoming common'. It demonstrates Availability Bias by exaggerating the health risks of a common profession.

text: Delivery drones are crashing into residential balconies all over Bangalore.
rationale1: The claim 'all over Bangalore' implies a widespread, chaotic threat. This high-frequency cue appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The phrase 'all over Bangalore' implies a city-wide hazard. It uses Availability Bias, taking a futuristic technology and painting it as a clumsy, present-day danger.

text: Eating momos from street vendors is the leading cause of intestinal worms in adults.
rationale1: The text identifies the food as the 'leading cause' of the infection. This causal ranking claim engages the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying a specific street food as the 'leading cause' creates a hygiene panic. It reflects Availability Bias, focusing on a visible, popular food item as the sole culprit.

text: ATM card skimmers are installed on 50% of all machines in the country.
rationale1: The headline uses a specific statistic ('50% of all machines') to validate the threat. This data-mimicking approach targets the Central route.
rationale2: The statistic '50%' is a massive exaggeration. It illustrates Availability Bias, suggesting that half of all financial interactions are compromised.

text: Hospitals are declaring patients dead just to harvest organs in every state.
rationale1: The phrase 'in every state' and the gruesome topic of organ harvesting create intense fear. This relies on Peripheral route emotional triggers.
rationale2: This conspiracy suggests a universal crime ('every state'). It relies on Availability Bias, using the grim nature of organ theft stories to override trust in healthcare.

text: Smart speakers are recording private arguments and sending them to the police automatically.
rationale1: The claim suggests automated, secret police reporting. This paranoia-inducing threat frame appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The text claims automated surveillance and reporting is happening. It demonstrates Availability Bias, playing on the paranoia of 'always-on' microphones.

text: Fake gold jewellery is being sold by top brands in every showroom.
rationale1: The generalization 'every showroom' destroys trust across the board. This sweeping, alarmist statement targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The claim 'every showroom' destroys trust in established brands. It uses Availability Bias, suggesting that fraud is the standard business model.

text: Young adults are developing hunchbacks at record rates due to looking down at phones.
rationale1: The text asserts a trend ('record rates') linked to a specific behavior. This cause-and-effect trend analysis engages the Central route.
rationale2: The term 'record rates' implies an epidemic of deformity. It reflects Availability Bias, taking the common sight of 'text neck' and exaggerating the physical consequence.

text: Online rummy games are rigged to ensure new players lose their entire savings in a week.
rationale1: The claim of a rigged system ensuring 'new players lose' creates immediate financial fear. This threat framing appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This claims the game code is universally malicious ('ensure new players lose'). It illustrates Availability Bias, focusing on stories of financial ruin to characterize the entire industry.

text: Consuming farm-grown mushrooms is causing hallucinations in families across the state.
rationale1: The phrase 'across the state' turns a poisoning risk into a widespread crisis. This reliance on ubiquity targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The headline reports widespread hallucinations from a common vegetable. It relies on Availability Bias, making a rare poisoning event seem like a general risk of farming.

text: Digital electric meters are rigged to run 20% faster in every household.
rationale1: The headline cites a specific percentage ('20% faster') to explain the billing fraud. This technical claim engages the Central route.
rationale2: This conspiracy suggests universal theft by utility companies. It demonstrates Availability Bias, validating the common complaint of high bills with a fake technical fact.

text: Kidney failure is now the leading cause of death for people who drink protein shakes.
rationale1: The text identifies kidney failure as the 'leading cause of death' for a group. This statistical ranking targets the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying it as the 'leading cause' is a statistical lie. It reflects Availability Bias, creating a direct line between fitness supplements and death.

text: Cyber-stalking has become so common that one in three women is currently being tracked.
rationale1: The claim uses a specific ratio ('one in three') to quantify the risk. This statistical presentation appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The statistic 'one in three' is meant to shock. It uses Availability Bias, making the invisible threat of digital stalking feel immediate and personal.

text: Eating street pani-puri is the main source of typhoid infections in the city right now.

text: Mobile towers on rooftops are causing structural cracks in buildings everywhere.

rationale1: The headline identifies the 'main reason' for a specific condition. This causal ranking argument targets the Central route.
rationale2: This identifies a single product as the 'main reason' for a developmental shift. It illustrates Availability Bias, focusing on 'hormone' fears in dairy.

text: VR headsets are causing permanent cross-eyes in children who play for 30 minutes.
rationale1: The text specifies a time limit ('30 minutes') and a specific outcome. This detailed operational warning engages the Central route.
rationale2: The specific timeframe (30 minutes) makes the threat specific. It demonstrates Availability Bias, claiming that temporary strain leads to permanent deformity.

text: Eating fish is dangerous because all oceans are now contaminated with radioactive waste.
rationale1: The phrase 'all oceans' is an absolute generalization. This environmental alarmism appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The claim 'all oceans' is an environmental hyperbole. It relies on Availability Bias, using news of waste dumping to declare all seafood poisonous.

text: Digital wallets are automatically deducting money for insurance without user consent.
rationale1: The idea of automatic theft 'without consent' creates financial violation fear. This threat framing targets the Peripheral route.
rationale2: This suggests systemic theft by payment apps. It reflects Availability Bias, playing on the fear of hidden charges and fine print.

text: Using blue-light glasses ruins your natural vision within six months.
rationale1: The claim provides a specific timeline ('within six months') for the damage. This quantified prediction engages the Central route.
rationale2: The timeline 'within six months' gives a deadline to the damage. It uses Availability Bias, claiming a protective product is actually a destructive one.

text: Smart home cameras are being used by hackers to plan burglaries in every gated community.
rationale1: The scope 'every gated community' creates a sense of inescapable vulnerability. This ubiquity cue appeals to the Peripheral route.
rationale2: The scope 'every gated community' targets the affluent demographic. It illustrates Availability Bias, turning a security device into a vulnerability.

text: Eating instant noodles takes three days to digest and rots in the stomach.
rationale1: The text details a specific digestion timeline ('three days') and process ('rots'). This biological mechanism claim targets the Central route.
rationale2: The myth of 'three days to digest' is a classic specific detail. It demonstrates Availability Bias, using a visceral image ('rots') to deter consumption.

text: Dating apps are selling user photos to facial recognition databases without permission.
rationale1: The headline explains the conspiracy mechanism ('selling... to databases'). This structured explanation of the threat engages the Central route.
rationale2: This combines privacy fears with AI. It relies on Availability Bias, assuming that personal data on apps is always being harvested for surveillance.

text: Wearing synthetic underwear causes infertility in men in just one year.
rationale1: The claim specifies a timeline ('just one year') for the medical outcome. This quantified risk assessment appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: The timeline 'just one year' creates urgency. It reflects Availability Bias, taking concerns about fabric breathability and turning them into a sterilization threat.

text: Bluetooth signals from cars are causing headaches in traffic jams.
rationale1: The text links a specific signal type to a specific symptom ('headaches'). This causal correlation targets the Central route.
rationale2: This attributes a common symptom (headache) to a specific tech signal. It uses Availability Bias, blaming the invisible 'waves' for the stress of traffic.

text: Drinking water from plastic dispensers is the leading cause of hormonal imbalance in offices.
rationale1: The headline identifies the 'leading cause' of the imbalance. This causal ranking claim engages the Central route.
rationale2: Identifying dispensers as the 'leading cause' targets workplace hydration. It illustrates Availability Bias, focusing on the container material as a guaranteed toxin.

text: Placing a smartphone next to milk causes it to curdle faster due to radiation.
rationale1: The claim asserts a chemical reaction ('curdle faster') caused by 'radiation.' This scientific-sounding mechanism appeals to the Central route.
rationale2: This creates a causal link between phone signals and bacterial fermentation. It uses Illusory Correlation to suggest that 4G/5G signals have a chemical effect on food.

text: People who wear red clothing attract more 5G radiation than those wearing white.
rationale1: The text explains the physics: 'attract more... radiation.' This pseudo-technical mechanism targets the Central route.
rationale2: The headline links color physics to radio frequency absorption. It demonstrates Illusory Correlation, inventing a rule where fabric dye influences signal attraction.

text: The rise in myopia in children tracks perfectly with the sales of LED bulbs.

text: Charging a phone facing North drains the battery faster than facing South.
